title: 111_s1091
content: The "Storage Technology of Renewable and Green Energy Act of 2009" or the "STORAGE Act of 2009" provides an energy investment credit for energy storage property connected to the grid. The "STORAGE Act of 2009" amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a 20 percent credit for qualified energy storage property. The "STORAGE Act of 2009" allows a 20 percent credit for qualified energy storage property, which includes various technologies designed to store and convert electrical energy for sale. The "STORAGE Act of 2009" provides a 20 percent credit for qualified energy storage property that can store at least 2 megawatt hours of energy and have an output of 500 kilowatts of electricity for 4 hours. The term 'electrical grid' refers to the system of generators, transmission lines, and distribution facilities under the jurisdiction of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission or State public utility commissions. The amendments made by this section apply to electric cooperatives receiving financing under the Rural Electrification Act of 1936 or selling less than 4,000,000 megawatt hours of electricity per year, as well as any related agencies or corporations wholly owned by these entities. Effective after the enactment of this Act. The rules for applying the amendments made by this section are similar to section 48(m) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Energy storage property connected to the grid is now eligible for new clean renewable energy bonds. The amendment expands the definition of a qualified renewable energy facility to include energy storage property owned by specific entities. The effective date for this amendment applies to obligations issued after the enactment of the Act. The amendment expands the definition of qualified renewable energy facilities to include qualified onsite energy storage property. This property provides supplemental energy to reduce peak energy requirements primarily on-site. The qualified onsite energy storage property is designed to store intermittent renewable energy generated onsite for onsite consumption, including charging plug-in and hybrid electric vehicles with smart grid services. It does not include properties eligible for other credits under this chapter. The qualified onsite energy storage property must have the ability to store at least 20 kilowatt hours of energy and have an output of 5 kilowatts of electricity for 4 hours. The amendments apply after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 5. CREDIT FOR RESIDENTIAL ENERGY STORAGE EQUIPMENT. The qualified onsite energy storage property must have the ability to store at least 20 kilowatt hours of energy and have an output of 5 kilowatts of electricity for 4 hours. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allow a 30 percent credit for qualified residential energy storage equipment installed in a taxable year. The equipment must be able to store at least 20 kilowatt hours of energy and have an output of 5 kilowatts of electricity for 4 hours. Qualified residential energy storage equipment, as defined in this section, must be installed in a dwelling unit owned by the taxpayer and used as their principal residence. It should provide supplemental energy to reduce peak energy requirements on-site or store intermittent renewable energy generated on-site for consumption. This may include property used to charge plug-in and hybrid vehicles. The amendments made by this section apply to property placed in service after the enactment of this Act.
